title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement [INSERT CONTACT METHOD]. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.0, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/0/ code_of_conduct.html. title: Contributing to insane
text: want make bigger change, ’s good idea first file issue make sure someone team agrees ’s needed. ’ve found bug, please file issue illustrates bug minimal reprex (also help write unit test, needed).

title: Contributing to insane
text: Fork package clone onto computer. haven’t done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("mcanouil/insane", fork = TRUE). Install development dependences devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e. just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.

title: Contributing to insane
text: New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use testthat unit tests. Contributions test cases included easier accept.

title: Contributing to insane
text: Please note insane project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project agree abide terms.

title: insane: INsulin Secretion ANalysEr
text: Shiny (R package) application insane (INsulin Secretion ANalysEr) provides web interactive tool import experiments insulin secretion using cell lines EndoC-βH1.

text: Excel template provided within app help users import experiments easy way.

title: insane: INsulin Secretion ANalysEr
text: insane provides user-friendly interface can handle several projects separately.

title: insane: INsulin Secretion ANalysEr
text: insane performs technical quality-control optical density measured steps experiments: blank (BLANK), lysat (LYSATE), supernatant (SUPERNATANT1 SUPERNATANT2). technical quality-control step checks: variability among duplicated optical density measures samples; variability blank curves (intercept slope estimates) among experiments project.

title: insane: INsulin Secretion ANalysEr
text: insane performs statistical analyses experimental conditions, e.g., one silenced gene (siGENE) compared insulin secretion reference (siNTP) two stimulation conditions (Glc Glc + ). Conditions compared using linear regression Date Operator covariates (needed) control heterogeneity. Using experiments selected project Boxplot version  Histogram version  Using experiments selected project  experiments failing technical quality-controls, summary issues regarding selected experiments can displayed using button Show Issues Selected Experiments.

title: insane: INsulin Secretion ANalysEr
text: comprehensive list issues detected selected project available Outliers tab.  Note: Outliers tab displayed least one issue selected project.

title: insane: Experimental Protocol
text: EndoC-βH1 cells cultured Optiβ medium (Univercell). Cells seeded density 2.5 × 106 T25 flasks coated β-coat (Univercell) according manufacturer’s instructions, cultured 37 °C 5 % CO2.

what: Transfection of siRNA into EndoC-βH1 cells
title: insane: Experimental Protocol
text: case transfection, siRNAs transfected EndoC-βH1 cells using Lipofectamine 2000 (Invitrogen). Freshly trypsinized EndoC-βH1 (0.5 × 106 cells) incubated suspension Lipofectamine-siRNA complex Opti-MEM (Invitrogen) containing 50 μM 2-mercaptoethanol, 10 mM nicotinamide (Calbiochem, Merck Millipore), 5.5 mg/ml human transferrin (Sigma-Aldrich), 6.7 ng/ml sodium selenite (Sigma-Aldrich), 100 U/ml penicillin 100 mg/ml streptomycin (Life Technologies) 10 minutes plated onto culture wells coated β-oat (Univercell). Six hours later, medium replaced. previously used -TARGETplus siRNA SMARTpool gene interest (20-30 nM) -TARGETplus nontargeting pool controls (siNTP; Dharmacon, Thermo Fisher Scientific, Waltham, MA, USA) (Ndiaye et al. 2017). Cells analyzed 72 hours post transfection.

what: Assessment of insulin secretion from EndoC-βH1 cells
title: insane: Experimental Protocol
text: EndoC-βH1 cells seeded onto β-coat-coated 96-well plates 5 × 104 cells/well incubated overnight glucose Dulbecco’s Modified Eagle’s Medium (Sigma Aldrich) supplemented 2 % BSA Fraction V, 50 μM 2-mercaptoethanol, 10 mM nicotinamide (Calbiochem, Merck Millipore), 5.5 mg/ml human transferrin (Sigma-Aldrich), 6.7 ng/ml sodium selenite (Sigma-Aldrich), 100 U/ml penicillin 100 mg/ml streptomycin (Life Technologies) contained 2.8 mM glucose. day , incubated HEPES-buffered Krebs-Ringer Buffer (KRB; 116 mmol/l NaCl, 5.06 mmol/l KCl, 1.007 mmol/l CaCl2, 1.01 mmol/l MgCl2, 23.96 mmol/l NaHCO3, 10 mmol/l HEPES, pH 7.4, 0.1 % BSA solution) contained 0.5 mM glucose ± 0.5 mM IBMX (Sigma Aldrich) 60 minutes 37 °C. supernatant subsequently collected (supernatant 1 [SN1]) replaced 16.7 mM glucose KRB ± 0.5 mM IBMX 60-minute incubation 37 °C collected (supernatant 2 [SN2]). insulin content measurement, cells lysed TETG buffer (20 mM Tris-HCl pH 8.0, 137 mM NaCl, 1 % Triton X-100, 10 % Glycerol, 2 mM EGTA protease inhibitors; Roche). Lysate, SN1 SN2 centrifuged 5 minutes 700 g. Samples kept frozen -20 °C use. Insulin concentration supernatants intracellular content EndoC-βH1 cells measured ELISA according manufacturer’s instructions using Human Insulin Kit (Mercodia, Uppsala, Sweden). Briefly, 25 µl either blank, standard (0.2 6 µg/ml), diluted samples (1:400 lysates 1:16 supernatants) 100 µl 1X conjugate enzyme put 96-well plate coated insulin antibody 1 hour agitation room temperature. plate washed six times wash buffer 1X solution. , 200 µl substrate added plate 15-minute incubation. , 50 µl stop solution added absorbance 450 nm measured, using technical duplicates experimental triplicates, leading six measurements per experimental conditions (subsequently repeated). Note: absorbance values need written within Excel template provided insane package.

text: Mickaël Canouil. Author, maintainer.

title: INsulin Secretion ANalysEr
text: user-friendly interface, using Shiny, analyse glucose-stimulated insulin secretion (GSIS) assays pancreatic beta cells islets. package allows user import several sets experiments different spreadsheets perform subsequent steps: summarise tidy format, visualise data quality compare experimental conditions without omitting account technical confounders date experiment technician. Together, insane comprehensive method optimises pre-processing analyses GSIS experiments friendly-user interface. Shiny App initially designed EndoC-betaH1 cell line following method described Ndiaye et al., 2017 (https://doi.org/10.1016/j.molmet.2017.03.011).

title: Deploy the Shiny App — deploy
text: Deploy (copy) shiny application specified directory

title: Deploy the Shiny App — deploy
code: deploy(   directory = "/srv/shiny-server",   app_name = "insane",   demo = FALSE,   overwrite = FALSE )

title: Deploy the Shiny App — deploy
text: directory [character] character vector one path new location. app_name [character] character vector defining shiny application name new location. demo [logical] logical indicating examples spreadsheets copied app. overwrite [logical] logical indicating existing destination files overwritten.

title: Deploy the Shiny App — deploy
text: [logical] logical indicating whether deployment successfull (TRUE) (FALSE).

title: Run the Shiny Application — go_insane
text: Runs Shiny application. function normally return; interrupt R stop application (usually pressing Ctrl+C Esc).

title: Run the Shiny Application — go_insane
code: go_insane(   demo = FALSE,   port = getOption("shiny.port"),   launch.browser = getOption("shiny.launch.browser", interactive()),   host = getOption("shiny.host", "127.0.0.1"),   workerId = "",   quiet = FALSE,   display.mode = c("auto", "normal", "showcase"),   test.mode = getOption("shiny.testmode", FALSE) )

title: Run the Shiny Application — go_insane
text: demo [logical] logical indicating examples spreadsheets copied app. port TCP port application listen . port specified, shiny.port option set (options(shiny.port = XX)), port used. Otherwise, use random port 3000:8000, excluding ports blocked Google Chrome considered unsafe: 3659, 4045, 5060, 5061, 6000, 6566, 6665:6669 6697. twenty random ports tried. launch.browser true, system's default web browser launched automatically app started. Defaults true interactive sessions . value parameter can also function call application's URL. host IPv4 address application listen . Defaults shiny.host option, set, "127.0.0.1" . See Details. workerId Can generally ignored. Exists help editions Shiny Server Pro route requests correct process. quiet Shiny status messages shown? Defaults FALSE. display.mode mode display application. set value "showcase", shows application code metadata DESCRIPTION file application directory alongside application. set "normal", displays application normally. Defaults "auto", displays application mode given DESCRIPTION file, . test.mode application launched test mode? used recording running automated tests. Defaults shiny.testmode option, FALSE option set.

title: Run the Shiny Application — go_insane
code: if (interactive()) {   library(insane)   # Must be run in an interactive R session!   go_insane() }
